title: 107_hr1165
content: The Act titled "Election Voting Systems Standards Act of 2001" establishes the Election Voting Systems Standards Commission. The Election Voting Systems Standards Commission is established by the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology in consultation with the chairman of the Federal Election Commission. The Commission consists of members including the Director of NIST as chair, the FEC chairman as vice-chair, representatives from the National Association of State Election Directors, the National Governors Association, and the American National Standards Institute. The Election Voting Systems Standards Commission, established by the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology, includes members selected by the Director in consultation with various government officials. The Commission is responsible for setting technical standards and criteria for voting products and systems used in Federal elections. The Election Voting Systems Standards Commission, established by the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology, is responsible for setting technical standards and criteria for voting products and systems used in Federal elections. The Commission shall develop uniform testing and evaluation procedures for voting products and systems to ensure conformance to the established standards. Additionally, procedures for certification of non-Federal laboratories to perform testing and evaluation shall be established by the Commission. The Election Voting Systems Standards Commission will develop testing and evaluation procedures for voting products and systems, along with recommendations for promoting their use. A report containing the procedures and recommendations must be submitted to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. SEC. 3. NATIONAL ELECTION SYSTEMS STANDARDS LABORATORY. The Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology will choose an organization to operate the National Election Systems Standards Laboratory. The selection will be based on established criteria and through a merit-based competition open to nonpartisan research entities. The Laboratory's functions include investigating issues related to voting products and systems, focusing on human factors in design and remote-access voting systems. The National Institute of Standards and Technology will select an organization to operate the National Election Systems Standards Laboratory based on merit. The Laboratory will focus on investigating voting products and systems, including human factors in design and remote-access voting systems. Non-Federal laboratories will be certified to test and evaluate voting products, with a list of certified products made available to the public.
